metadata.case_name: Petitioner (Trader at Meerut) v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioner is a trader at Meerut ordered by the Income-tax Officer, D-Ward, Meerut, to pay Rs. 1,800/- as annuity deposit under Ch. XXII-A of the Income-tax Act, 1961.
Indian Income-tax Act 43 of 1961 enacted to consolidate and amend law relating to income-tax and super-tax, came into force on April 1, 1962.
Finance Act 5 of 1964 introduced Ch. XXII-A (ss. 280-A to 280-X) into Income-tax Act requiring certain taxpayers to make annuity deposits for assessment year commencing April 1, 1964.

Annuity deposit required from resident taxpayers with total income exceeding Rs. 15,000: Indian citizens (individuals), HUF, unregistered firms, associations/bodies of individuals (not companies/co-op societies), artificial juridical persons under s.2(31)(vii) not corporations by statute.
Non-residents, companies, co-operative societies, corporations by Central/State/Provincial Acts exempted from annuity deposits.

Taxpayer may opt out of deposit by notice to ITO before June 30 of assessment year; option irrevocable for that and subsequent years; opt-out requires payment of income-tax plus additional income-tax equal to half the amount saved by not depositing (exempt for individuals >70 years on last day of previous year).
Deposit based on adjusted total income at rates 5% to 12.5% per Second Schedule to Finance Act; total income computed without s.280-O allowance.
Authors, playwrights, artists, musicians, actors may deposit up to 25% of profession income optionally; gratuity recipients up to 50% of taxable gratuity optionally.
Annuity deposit repayable in 10 annual equated instalments of principal and interest; deposit deductible in computing total income for tax; instalments chargeable to tax as earned income when due.
ITO may require advance deposit per s.280-E; demand notices issuable/modifiable post-assessment.
Depositor may estimate lower adjusted income before last instalment.
Failure to pay deposit/penalty up to 50% of deposit; recoverable per Ch. XVII-D.
Commission income deferrable if periodic/not received/adjusted.
ITO recomputes on enhanced/reduced income, status change, firm registration cancellation.
Petition under Art. 32 challenging Ch. XXII-A as unconstitutional, violative of Art. 14.

legal_issues.text: Whether Parliament had competence to enact Ch. XXII-A in Income-tax Act (substantially borrowing, under Entry 82 or 97 List I).
Whether Ch. XXII-A is colourable exercise of legislative power, harsh/unconscionable/expropriatory.
Whether ss. 280 and Sch. II discriminatory, infringing Art. 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Parliament had no competence to incorporate borrowing provisions (Ch. XXII-A) in Income-tax Act under Entry 82 List I; should be separate under Entry 97.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 246, Entry 82 List I, Entry 97 List I

petitioner_arguments.text: Provisions colourable exercise of power, harsh/unconscionable/expropriatory, beyond legislative competence.
Provisions discriminatory (exemptions, progressive rates, age-based opt-out differences), violate Art. 14.

court_reasoning.text: Parliament competent under Entry 82 (taxes on income) and Entry 97 List I; no bar to combining in one Act; convenient to incorporate in Income-tax Act using its machinery.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No prohibition against single statute under multiple List I entries; closely related to income-tax levy.

court_reasoning.text: No colourable legislation; doctrine applies to disguised transgression of powers, not here where direct power exists; not expropriatory/merely harsh (taxing power not beyond Art. 13 scrutiny but harshness alone invalidates not).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parliament has power; no subterfuge; taxing statutes challengeable if expropriatory/single procedure lacking, not if harsh.

court_reasoning.text: No Art. 14 violation; reasonable classification (income >15k, higher slabs for savings mobilization/anti-inflation); progressive rates, exemptions rational; age >70 exemption reasonable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification bears nexus to objectives; optional scheme; reduced income-tax rates alongside.

court_reasoning.text: Hidayatullah J.: Pith and substance under Entry 82 (tax relief via deposit alternative); not borrowing under Art. 292 (executive); residuary Entry 97 last resort.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Annuity deposit in lieu of tax part; uses income-tax machinery; not obligatory.

holdings.text: Ch. XXII-A constitutionally valid; within Parliament's competence under Entries 82/97 List I; not colourable; not violative of Art. 14.
Doctrine of colourable legislation inapplicable where direct power exists.
Classification reasonable, not discriminatory under Art. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. C. Gajapati Narayan Deo v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains doctrine of colourable legislation does not involve bona fides; applies to disguised transgressions.
Earlier view taxing power transcends rights (overruled).

precedents_cited.case_name: Laxmanappa Hanumantappa v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier view taxing power transcends rights (overruled).

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Anantha Krishnan v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Earlier view by Venkatarama Ayyar J. taxing power transcends rights (overruled).

precedents_cited.case_name: Kunnathat Thathunni Moopil Nair v. State of Kerala
precedents_cited.relevance: Taxing statutes subject to Art. 13; challengeable if expropriatory/no procedure, not merely harsh.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1961
statutes_cited.relevance: Scheme for annuity deposits integrated with income-tax assessment/collection/deductions.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1964
statutes_cited.relevance: Introduced Ch. XXII-A; prescribed rates/explanation for deposits.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Competence, equality, fundamental rights scrutiny of tax laws.

statutes_cited.name: Compulsory Deposit Scheme Act, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Example of separate enactment; Parliament could incorporate in Income-tax Act.

outcome.summary: Writ petition challenging validity of Ch. XXII-A dismissed; provisions held constitutionally valid, within legislative competence, not colourable or discriminatory under Art. 14.

key_quotes.text: "The doctrine of colourable legislation does not involve any question of bona fides and mala fides on the part of the legislature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of colourable legislation doctrine.

key_quotes.text: "A taxing statute may accordingly be open to challenge on the ground that it is expropriatory or that the statute prescribes no procedure or machinery for assessing tax, but it is not open to challenge merely on the ground that the tax is harsh or excessive."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits grounds for challenging taxing statutes.

key_quotes.text: "The pith and substance of the impugned provisions, therefore rightly belong to the topic of taxes on income."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Hidayatullah J. on legislative competence under Entry 82.
